S1.T1.caption: TABLE I: Main notations
S1.T1.table:
n𝑛n number of client nodes
d𝑑d dimension of raw feature space
q𝑞q dimension of transformed feature space
[n],n∈ℕdelimited-[]𝑛𝑛ℕ[n],\,n{\in}\mathbb{N} set {1,…,n}1…𝑛\{1,\ldots,n\}
ℓj,j∈[n]subscriptℓ𝑗𝑗delimited-[]𝑛\ell_{j},\,j{\in}[n] number of data points in j𝑗j-th client’s dataset Djsubscript𝐷𝑗D_{j}
m𝑚m number of data points across all clients
𝜽r,r∈{1,2,…}superscript𝜽𝑟𝑟12…\bm{\theta}^{r},\,r{\in}\{1,2,\ldots\} global model after r𝑟r-th training iteration
references: We organize the rest of our paper as follows. In Table I, we list the main notations for convenience. Section II presents a technical background on federated learning, and our proposed compute and communication models for MEC. Section III describes our proposed CodedFedL scheme. In Section IV, we analyze the load allocation policy in CodedFedL. We provide the results of our numerical experiments in Section V, and provide our concluding remarks in Section VI. All technical proofs are provided in the Appendix.

references: Clearly, CodedFedL has significantly better convergence time than the naive uncoded and greedy uncoded approaches, and as highlighted in Section III-E, the coded federated gradient aggregation approximates the naive uncoded gradient aggregation well for large datasets. For further insight, let γ𝛾\gamma be the target accuracy for a dataset, while tγUsuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝛾𝑈t_{\gamma}^{U}, tγGsuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝛾𝐺t_{\gamma}^{G} and tγCsuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝛾𝐶t_{\gamma}^{C} respectively be the first time instants to reach the γ𝛾\gamma accuracy for naive uncoded, greedy uncoded and CodedFedL. In Table II, we summarize the results where δ=ψ=0.1𝛿𝜓0.1\delta{=}\psi{=}0.1. Gains in the overall training time for CodedFedL are up to 2.5×2.5\times and 8.8×8.8\times over naive uncoded and greedy uncoded respectively. In Table III, we compare results for δ=ψ=0.2𝛿𝜓0.2\delta{=}\psi{=}0.2, where the gains in the training time for the target accuracy are up to 5.4×5.4\times and 15×15\times over naive uncoded and greedy uncoded respectively. Also, greedy uncoded never reaches the target accuracy of 93.3%percent93.393.3\% for MNIST and 82.8%percent82.882.8\% for Fashion MNIST, hence the corresponding fields in Tables II and III are empty.

references: Clearly, CodedFedL has significantly better convergence time than the naive uncoded and greedy uncoded approaches, and as highlighted in Section III-E, the coded federated gradient aggregation approximates the naive uncoded gradient aggregation well for large datasets. For further insight, let γ𝛾\gamma be the target accuracy for a dataset, while tγUsuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝛾𝑈t_{\gamma}^{U}, tγGsuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝛾𝐺t_{\gamma}^{G} and tγCsuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝛾𝐶t_{\gamma}^{C} respectively be the first time instants to reach the γ𝛾\gamma accuracy for naive uncoded, greedy uncoded and CodedFedL. In Table II, we summarize the results where δ=ψ=0.1𝛿𝜓0.1\delta{=}\psi{=}0.1. Gains in the overall training time for CodedFedL are up to 2.5×2.5\times and 8.8×8.8\times over naive uncoded and greedy uncoded respectively. In Table III, we compare results for δ=ψ=0.2𝛿𝜓0.2\delta{=}\psi{=}0.2, where the gains in the training time for the target accuracy are up to 5.4×5.4\times and 15×15\times over naive uncoded and greedy uncoded respectively. Also, greedy uncoded never reaches the target accuracy of 93.3%percent93.393.3\% for MNIST and 82.8%percent82.882.8\% for Fashion MNIST, hence the corresponding fields in Tables II and III are empty.
